column4: could someone tell me how the bash command export works? I have two scripts, the first should set many environment variables with export, then the second would like to use them. The first gives no error, but the second still doesn't have the variables set. Any ideas?
does the first script run the second script?
no, should it? can't these variables set globally by export?
changing the environment can only affect children of that process
thx, I'll try that way then
at that point, it might as well be all one script
yes, I realised it as well :)
though you can still export within the script, if the script runs programs that expect certain env variables to be set
and is it possible to call the "settings" script from the other scripts (plural now!) to set the environment variable for the main script?
exactly, that's what I would like
isn't that what the export command is for?

say i want any program that uses the EDITOR variable to use 'vim'. i can export EDITOR=vim in my .bashrc, and any children of my bash shell will inherit that variable. so when i run crontab, for example (which uses EDITOR), it opens my crontab with vim
so by 'global', you probably mean variables that are set in your .bashrc or .xsessionrc
but then what is the "export" command for? Can't I set ".bashrc level" variables later?
if I didn't export EDITOR, crontab in the above example would not receive the value 'vim'
I think I understand it now, more or less :)
export makes it so that child processes of a certain process can inherit the value of a variable
